__data__.text:
Gamatrain is an educational technology company (EdTech) that provides AI-powered learning tools.
    Gamatrain AI is an intelligent educational assistant created by Gamatrain's development team.
    Gamatrain helps students learn through personalized education and smart tutoring.
Gamatrain AI can help students with math, science, and language learning. It provides personalized tutoring based on each student's level.
To reset your Gamatrain password, go to Settings > Account > Reset Password. You will receive an email with instructions.
Gamatrain supports Persian (Farsi), English, and Arabic languages for educational content.
The Gamatrain mobile app is available on both iOS and Android. Download from App Store or Google Play.
Gamatrain pricing: Free tier includes basic features. Premium subscription costs $9.99/month with full access to all courses.

Blog Title: The Tennis Court Oath of 1789

URL: /blog/period-t

Blog Title: Oscillation
Summary: A repeated to-and-fro motion about a central point or equilibrium position. Also known as vibratory motion.
URL: /blog/oscillation

Blog Title: Natural Frequency
Summary: An object's inherent vibration rate. When excited, it resonates with maximum amplitude and energy transfer.
URL: /blog/natural-frequency

Blog Title: Free Oscillation
Summary: The oscillation of a body that is set in motion and then left to oscillate without any external forces, oscillating at its natural frequency.
URL: /blog/free-oscillation

Blog Title: Forced Oscillation
Summary: An oscillation that occurs when an external periodic force drives the system.
URL: /blog/forced-oscillation

Blog Title: Damped Oscillation
Summary: Motion slows as energy fades. A damped oscillation gradually quiets, its amplitude shrinking with each passing cycle.
URL: /blog/damped-oscillation

Blog Title: Antinode
Summary: A point in a stationary wave where the amplitude of oscillation is at a maximum.
URL: /blog/antinode

Blog Title: Angular Frequency (ω)
Summary: The rate of change of phase with time, measured in radians per second (rad s⁻¹).
URL: /blog/angular-frequency-

Blog Title: Orbiting
Summary: The motion of an object, such as a satellite or planet, as it travels around another object in space under the influence of gravity
URL: /blog/orbiting1

Blog Title: Radial Field 
Summary: A gravitational field that spreads out equally in all directions from a point mass, like the field around a planet or star.
URL: /blog/radial-field

Blog Title: Orbital Period 
Summary: The time taken for a satellite or planet to complete one full orbit around another celestial body.
URL: /blog/orbital-period

Blog Title: Gravitational Potential Energy (Eₚ) 
Summary: The energy a mass possesses by virtue of its position in a gravitational field.
URL: /blog/gravitational-potential-energy-e

Blog Title: Gravitational Potential (φ)
Summary: The work done per unit mass in bringing a small test mass from infinity to a point in a gravitational field.
URL: /blog/gravitational-potential-

Blog Title: Gravitational Field Strength (g)
Summary: The force per unit mass experienced by a small test mass placed in a gravitational field.
URL: /blog/gravitational-field-strength-g

Blog Title: Gravitational Field
Summary: A region of space surrounding a mass where another mass experiences a force of attraction.
URL: /blog/gravitational-field

Blog Title: Steady Speed, Changing Velocity
Summary: An object moves steadily in a circle. Its speed is constant; velocity constantly changes.
URL: /blog/steady-speed-changing-velocity

Blog Title: Circular Motion
Summary: Motion of an object along a circular path.
URL: /blog/circular-motion

Blog Title: Centripetal Force
Summary: The resultant force acting on an object moving in a circular path, directed towards the centre of the circle.
URL: /blog/centripetal-force

Blog Title: Centripetal Acceleration
Summary: The acceleration of an object moving in a circular path. It is always directed towards the centre of the circle.
URL: /blog/centripetal-acceleration

Blog Title: Angular Speed (ω)
Summary: The rate of change of angular displacement. It is calculated as the angle turned through per unit time.
URL: /blog/angular-speed-

Blog Title: Angular Displacement (θ)
Summary: The angle through which an object moving in a circle has rotated, measured in radians.
URL: /blog/angular-displacement-

Blog Title: Decay constant (λ)
Summary: The probability that a given nucleus will decay per unit time.
URL: /blog/decay-constant-

Blog Title: Beta (β) decay
Summary: A type of radioactive decay in which an atomic nucleus emits a beta particle.
URL: /blog/beta-decay

Blog Title: Alpha (α) decay
Summary: A type of radioactive decay in which an atomic nucleus emits an alpha particle.
URL: /blog/alpha-decay

Blog Title:  Radioactivity
Summary: Is the spontaneous disintegration of unstable atomic nuclei, releasing energetic particles.
URL: /blog/radioactivity

Blog Title: Radioactive decay
Summary: Is the spontaneous process where an unstable nucleus emits radiation to achieve stability.
URL: /blog/radioactive-decay

Blog Title: Proton
Summary: A stable, positively charged subatomic particle residing in the atomic nucleus, defining the element's identity and atomic number.
URL: /blog/proton

Blog Title: Nucleus (pl. nuclei)
Summary: The atom's dense, central nucleus contains protons and neutrons, defining the element.
URL: /blog/nucleus-pl.-nuclei

Blog Title:  Nucleon
Summary: A nucleon is a collective term for the particles residing in an atomic nucleus: protons and neutrons.
URL: /blog/nucleon

Blog Title: Neutron
Summary: The neutron is a neutral subatomic particle residing within an atom's nucleus, crucial for stability.
URL: /blog/neutron

Blog Title: Mass number (A)
Summary: Defines an atom's nucleus, representing the combined total of its protons and neutrons. It determines the isotope.


URL: /blog/mass-number-a

Blog Title: Beta-particle (β-particle)
Summary: A β-particle is a high-speed electron or positron emitted from an atomic nucleus during radioactive decay.
URL: /blog/beta-particle-particle

Blog Title: Atomic number (Z)
Summary: An element's identity is determined by its atomic number—the proton count in its nucleus.


URL: /blog/atomic-number-z

Blog Title: Atom
Summary: An atom is the fundamental unit of matter, the smallest component of an element retaining its unique chemical properties.
URL: /blog/atom

Blog Title: Alpha-particle (α-particle)
Summary: A positively charged particle consisting of two protons and two neutrons, identical to a helium nucleus.
URL: /blog/alpha-particle-particle

Blog Title: Progressive Wave
Summary: A wave that transfers energy from one place to another, in contrast to a stationary wave which does not transfer energy.
URL: /blog/progressive-wave

Blog Title:  Harmonics
Summary: Frequencies at which stationary waves are formed that are integer multiples of the fundamental frequency.
URL: /blog/harmonics

Blog Title: Fundamental Frequency
Summary: The lowest frequency at which a stationary wave is formed.
URL: /blog/fundamental-frequency

Blog Title: Speed of Sound
Summary: Sound's speed in a medium defines the fixed wavelengths and frequencies possible for its stationary, resonant wave patterns.
URL: /blog/speed-of-sound

Blog Title: Wavelength (of a Stationary Wave)
Summary: Between two nodes or antinodes lies the stationary wave's wavelength, a fundamental spatial measure of its repeating pattern.
URL: /blog/wavelength-of-a-stationary-wave

Blog Title: Young's Double-Slit Experiment

URL: /blog/youngs-double-slit-experiment

Blog Title: Stationary Wave (or Standing Wave)
Summary: A wave pattern formed by the superposition of two progressive waves of the same frequency and amplitude travelling in opposite directions.
URL: /blog/stationary-wave-or-standing-wave

Blog Title:  Principle of Superposition of Waves
Summary: Waves superimpose; their net displacement is the sum of individual displacements at every point.
URL: /blog/principle-of-superposition-of-waves

Blog Title: Path Difference
Summary: The difference in the distance travelled by two waves from their sources to a specific point.
URL: /blog/path-difference

Blog Title: Interference
Summary: The combined effect of two or more wave trains superposing (meeting) at a point.
URL: /blog/interference

Blog Title: Diffraction Grating
Summary: A plate with many parallel, equally spaced slits very close together.
URL: /blog/diffraction-grating

Blog Title: Coherent
Summary: Two sources of waves are coherent if they have a constant phase difference and the same frequency.
URL: /blog/coherent-two-sources-of-waves-are-coherent-if-they-have-a-constant-phase-difference-and-the-same-frequency.

Blog Title: Wavelength (λ)
Summary: The distance between two successive points in phase on a wave, such as from one crest to the next.
URL: /blog/wavelength-

Blog Title: Wave Speed (v)
Summary: The speed at which the wave energy is transferred. 
URL: /blog/wave-speed-v

Blog Title: Wave Energy
Summary: The energy carried by a wave, which is related to its amplitude.
URL: /blog/wave-energy

Blog Title: Wave
Summary: A regular, repeating pattern of disturbances that transfers energy from one point to another without the transfer of matter.
URL: /blog/wave

Blog Title: Transverse Wave
Summary: Particles oscillate perpendicularly to the wave's direction of travel, defining a transverse wave's fundamental nature.
URL: /blog/transverse-wave

Blog Title: Polarisation
Summary: Light's vibration confined to one plane defines polarization, a key wave property.
URL: /blog/polarisation

Blog Title: Orders of Magnitude
Summary: Vast scales compared using powers of ten, simplifying our universe's immense range from atoms to galaxies.
URL: /blog/orders-of-magnitude

Blog Title: Longitudinal Wave

URL: /blog/longitudinal-wave

Blog Title: Electromagnetic Waves

URL: /blog/electromagnetic-waves

Blog Title: Electromagnetic Radiation
Summary: Energy propagated through space via oscillating electric and magnetic field waves.
URL: /blog/electromagnetic-radiation1

Blog Title: Doppler Effect
Summary: The change in observed frequency (and wavelength) of a wave due to the relative motion between the source of the wave and the observer.
URL: /blog/doppler-effect

Blog Title: Diffraction
Summary: Waves spread and bend as they pass obstacles or gaps. This phenomenon, called diffraction, demonstrates the wave nature of light and sound.
URL: /blog/diffraction

Blog Title: Describing Waves
Summary: Waves are characterized by their amplitude, wavelength, frequency, period, and speed. This defines their energy and behavior.
URL: /blog/describing-waves

Blog Title: Amplitude
Summary: The maximum displacement of a particle from its equilibrium position.
URL: /blog/amplitude

Blog Title: Potentiometer Circuit
Summary: A circuit that uses a potentiometer to compare an unknown voltage with a known voltage, or to measure the e.m.f.
URL: /blog/potentiometer-circuit

Blog Title: Potentiometer
Summary: A three-terminal resistor with a sliding contact that forms an adjustable voltage divider.
URL: /blog/potentiometer

Blog Title: Sensor
Summary: This circuit employs series resistors to split a voltage into a smaller, desired fraction.
URL: /blog/sensor

Blog Title: Potential Divider
Summary: A potential divider uses series resistors to split a source voltage into a smaller, specific output voltage.
URL: /blog/potential-divider

Blog Title: Terminal Potential Difference (Terminal Voltage)
Summary: Powering a circuit, terminal voltage is the observed potential difference across a source's output under load.
URL: /blog/terminal-potential-difference-terminal-voltage

Blog Title: Internal Resistance
Summary: Internal resistance is the inherent opposition to current flow within a battery or power source itself.
URL: /blog/internal-resistance

Blog Title: Superconductor
Summary: A material that has zero electrical resistance below a certain critical temperature.
URL: /blog/superconductor

Blog Title: Resistivity (ρ)
Summary: Resistivity (ρ) is a material's intrinsic property quantifying its opposition to electric current.
URL: /blog/resistivity-

Blog Title: Filament Lamp
Summary: A filament lamp's resistance increases with temperature, making it non-ohmic.
URL: /blog/filament-lamp1

Blog Title: Non-Ohmic Conductor
Summary: A conductor whose resistance changes with voltage, thus disobeying Ohm's Law.
URL: /blog/non-ohmic-conductor

Blog Title: Ohmic Conductor
Summary: An ohmic conductor's resistance remains constant, obeying Ohm's Law with a linear V-I relationship.
URL: /blog/ohmic-conductor

Blog Title: Ohm's Law
Summary: Ohm's Law states the current through a conductor between two points is proportional to the voltage.
URL: /blog/ohms-law

Blog Title: I-V Characteristic
Summary: A graph showing how a component's current changes with the applied voltage across it.
URL: /blog/i-v-characteristic

Blog Title: Conservation of Charge
Summary: Charge is conserved; it cannot be created or destroyed, only transferred in any process.
URL: /blog/conservation-of-charge

Blog Title: Resistor Combinations
Summary: The ways in which resistors can be connected in a circuit, primarily in series or parallel.
URL: /blog/resistor-combinations

Blog Title: Electromotive Force (e.m.f., ε)
Summary: Electromotive force (e.m.f.) is the electrical energy produced per unit charge from other forms.
URL: /blog/electromotive-force-e.m.f.-

Blog Title: Loop
Summary: Any closed conducting path within a circuit.
URL: /blog/loop

Blog Title: Junction (or Node)
Summary: A point in a circuit where two or more wires or components are connected.
URL: /blog/junction-or-node

URL: /blog/kirchhoffs-second-law-also-known-as-the-law-of-conservation-of-energy-for-electrical-circuits.

Blog Title: Kirchhoff's First Law
Summary: Kirchhoff's First Law states current entering a junction equals current leaving it.
URL: /blog/kirchhoffs-first-law1

Blog Title: Electric Current (I)
Summary: The rate of flow of electric charge. Its SI unit is the ampere (A).
URL: /blog/electric-current-i

Blog Title: Volt (V)

URL: /blog/volt-v

Blog Title: Unit (for a quantity)

URL: /blog/unit-for-a-quantity

Blog Title: Symbol (for a quantity)
Summary: A letter used to represent a physical quantity in an equation. 
URL: /blog/symbol-for-a-quantity

Blog Title: Resistor

URL: /blog/resistor

Blog Title: Resistance (R)
Summary: A measure of how difficult it is for an electric current to pass through a component. 
URL: /blog/resistance-r

Blog Title: Power (P) (Electrical)
Summary: Electrical power is the rate of energy transfer in a circuit, measured in watts.
URL: /blog/power-p-electrical

Blog Title: Potential Difference (p.d.) / Voltage (V)

URL: /blog/potential-difference-p.d.-voltage-v

Blog Title: Electron
Summary: Flowing electrons create electric current in metals, a movement of negatively charged subatomic particles.
URL: /blog/electron

Blog Title: Electric Charge (Q)
Summary: Charge (Q): A fundamental property of matter causing force in an electric field.
URL: /blog/electric-charge-q

Blog Title: Direct Current (d.c.)
Summary: Direct current flows one way, consistently. It is supplied by sources like batteries and solar cells.
URL: /blog/direct-current-d.c.

Blog Title: Current (I) 
Summary: The rate of flow of electric charge. Its SI unit is the ampere (A).
URL: /blog/current-i

Blog Title: Circuit Diagram
Summary: A simplified representation of an electrical circuit using standard symbols for the components.
URL: /blog/circuit-diagram

Blog Title: Circuit
Summary: Current flows in a closed loop. This circuit requires a power source and a complete, unbroken conductive path to function.
URL: /blog/circuit

Blog Title: Alternating Current (a.c.)

URL: /blog/alternating-current-a.c.

Blog Title: Tensile force
Summary: A tensile force is a pulling load applied to a material, causing it to stretch and experience elongation along its axis.
URL: /blog/tensile-force

Blog Title: Spring constant (k)
Summary: A constant that represents the stiffness of a spring. 
URL: /blog/spring-constant-k

Blog Title: Pressure
Summary: Pressure is the force applied perpendicular to the surface of an object per unit area.
URL: /blog/pressure

Blog Title: Limit of proportionality
Summary: The point where a material's extension is no longer proportional to applied force.
URL: /blog/limit-of-proportionality

Blog Title: Hooke's law
Summary: Hooke's Law states a spring's extension is directly proportional to the applied force.
URL: /blog/hookes-law

Blog Title: Elastic potential energy
Summary: Elastic potential energy is stored when an object is deformed, like a stretched or compressed spring.
URL: /blog/elastic-potential-energy

Blog Title: Density
Summary: Density is a substance's mass per unit volume, determining its buoyancy and concentration.
URL: /blog/density

Blog Title: Compressive force
Summary: An inward, squeezing force that shortens an object and reduces its volume by compacting its material.
URL: /blog/compressive-force

Blog Title: Archimedes' principle
Summary: The buoyant force on an object equals the weight of displaced fluid.
URL: /blog/archimedes-principle

Blog Title: Two-Dimensional Collision
Summary: Analyzing two-dimensional collisions where objects diverge from a single straight path.


URL: /blog/two-dimensional-collision

Blog Title: System
Summary: A collection of two or more objects that are being considered together.
URL: /blog/system

Blog Title: Principle of Conservation of Momentum

URL: /blog/principle-of-conservation-of-momentum

Blog Title: Momentum

URL: /blog/momentum1

Blog Title: Explosion

URL: /blog/explosion

Blog Title: Elastic Collision

Blog Title: Conservation of Momentum

URL: /blog/conservation-of-momentum

Blog Title: Collision
Summary: A short-duration event where two or more bodies exert strong forces, causing a sudden change in their motion and momentum.


URL: /blog/collision

Blog Title: Work in physics

URL: /blog/work-in-physics

Blog Title: Watt (W)

URL: /blog/watt-w
